titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Irish Echo Photographs AIA.045
titlestmt.author: Marion Casey, Mary Corcoran, John Ridge, and Rachel Searcy
titlestmt.sponsor: Processing and encoding funded by a grant from the Irish government's Department of Foreign Affairs, Emigrant Support Programme.

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-12-11 09:05:31 -0500.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

physdesc.extent: in 13 record cartons, 1 manuscript box, 2 oversize flat boxes, and 6 photograph boxes.

did.abstract: The Irish Echo is a nationally circulated ethnic newspaper published weekly in New York City since 1928. The paper covers political, social, entertainment, and sporting news from both Ireland and Irish America, in addition to national and international content from the perspective of the Irish American community. This collection consists of the photographic prints, transparencies, and photographic slides used to produce The Irish Echo. Common subjects documented include Irish and Irish American politicians, society events, sporting events, musical groups, arts and cultural events, and visiting celebrities and dignitaries. The files provide visual documentation of Irish American communities and American assimilation processes in the late 20th century. Particularly rich are the images portraying the ways in which these populations negotiated their dual identities and transmuted cultural traditions.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Irish Echo is a nationally circulated ethnic newspaper published weekly in New York City.The paper was founded in 1928 by Charles Connolly, a native of Co. Monaghan. In 1955, Patrick J. Grimes, a native of Co. Offaly, purchased the paper, which was subsequently run by members of the Grimes family for the remainder of the twentieth century. In 2002 the newspaper was sold to Irish businessman Sean Finlay, who sold it to the Belfast Media Group in 2007. Máirtin Ó Muilleoir is the current CEO and publisher.

The paper covers political, social, entertainment, and sporting news from both Ireland and Irish America, with a robust classified section targeted at domestic help, legal notices, and construction employment. News stories featured in most daily newspapers also often received coverage, from the perspective of the Irish American community.

Sources:
Claire Grimes, "History of the Irish Echo," New York Irish History 8 (1993-1994)
A Salute To 75 Years of the Irish Echo (NY: Irish Echo, 2003)
James V. O'Connor, Resisting the Melting Pot through Ethnic Newspapers: History and Function of the Irish Echo (Ph.D., Temple University, 2008)
Patrick Farrelly and Eamon Lynch, "Censorship at the Irish Echo," The Blanket: A Journal of Protest and Disssent, 20 June 2003, online at http://indiamond6.ulib.iupui.edu:81/censorshipie.html

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyright (and related rights to publicity and privacy) to materials in this collection created by the Irish Echo are held by the newspaper. Permission to publish or reproduce materials to which they hold copyright must be secured from the copyright holder. Please contact the Tamiment Library for assistance with contacting the Irish Echo.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition Note
acqinfo.p: The Irish Echo's photo morgue was donated to the Archives of Irish America when the newspaper moved its editorial offices from midtown Manhattan to lower Manhattan in the summer of 2006. The accession number associated with this gift is 2007.045. Further additions to the collection were received by the archives in 2012.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Irish Echo Photographs; AIA 045; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information Note
processinfo.p: Professor of Irish Studies Marion Casey boxed The Irish Echo's photo morgue at the newspaper's current offices in lower Manhattan before transferring the collection to the Archives of Irish America. Although there was not any consistent order to the photographs, there was evidence of an attempt to organize individuals and subjects alphabetically, in addition to sporadic efforts in the 1970s through 1990s to group all photographs by the month in which they were published in the newspaper. In an effort to assist discovery and retrieval independent of the newspaper's content, a decision was made to solidify an alphabetical arrangement based on individuals, organizations, and subjects. The distinction between Ireland, Irish America, and the United States is original to the arrangement of materials at the newspaper's office – and is particularly pronounced with regards to politics and sports - and has been preserved in the series arrangement.

During processing, notations identifying individuals and the approximate dates of particular events were made in pencil on the backs of photographs. Additionally, many photos bear a notation such as "Pre-1970s, 1980s Box;" it should be noted that no such box exists. Finally, during the arranging process, some smaller sized photographs were separated and housed in snapshot boxes; snapshots comprise Boxes #14 - #19. Also removed were slides, oversize photographs, and oversize color separations, which are now located in Boxes 20, 21, and 22, respectively. All photographs retain original intellectual arrangement within their series or subseries.

A further donation of materials was received by the archives while the collection was being processed; these materials remain unprocessed and will be integrated into the current arrangement schema at a later date.

odd.head: Sponsor Note
odd.p: Detailed processing and encoding for this collection was made possible by a grant from the Irish government's Department of Foreign Affairs, Emigrant Support Programme.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of photographic prints, transparencies, and photographic slides used to produce The Irish Echo, but is not limited to images published in the newspaper. The majority of the images in the collection were submitted by The Irish Echo staff and contract photographers, although some photographs were sent to the paper by unsolicited individuals. Photographers for The Irish Echo featured in this collection include John Bourke, Peter Dolan, Kevin Kennedy, Tom Matthews, and Michael O'Rourke. Also represented, particularly in Series V. Artists and Series VI. Film, Television, and Theatre, are publicity photographs from a variety of sources, including public relations firms and production studios.

The majority of photographs featured in The Irish Echo's photo morgue document Irish and Irish American people and communities, news events, and subjects throughout the greater New York City area. The collection also features numerous American and international figures and organizations interacting with Irish American communities. Politicians, society events, sporting events, schools and youth organizations, musical groups, arts and cultural events, as well as visiting celebrities and dignitaries are among the most common subjects documented throughout the collection.

The files are particularly rich in images related to Irish immigration and American assimilation processes during the latter half of the 20th century. Numerous images of Irish and Irish American communities and their leaders provide visual documentation of the ways in which these populations negotiated their dual identities and transmuted cultural traditions. Furthermore, the materials featured in this collection provide insight on editorial decisions regarding the prioritization of news, specifically as it pertains to content.

The majority of the collection consists of images taken in the United States, with the exception of Series II, which documents tourism, business, politics, sports, and various other topics specific to Ireland. Additionally, there is no distinction made within Series V - VII between Irish and American origins. For example, images in Series V. Artists, include photographs taken of American artists in Ireland as well as of Irish artists in America. Due to the multifaceted nature of the collection's images, individual events, people, or subjects may appear in multiple locations throughout the collection or within a single series.

Many of the prints show permanent evidence of their use, including crop marks, retouching by highlighting or shading, or other manipulation of the image. These marks are part of the record of a working newspaper and have been preserved as part of the history of The Irish Echo's photograph morgue. With the advent of digital photography and other technologies, the quantity of photos included in the collection declines beginning in the late 1990s, continuing steadily downward to 2004, which represents the latest date in the collection.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p:
Archives of Irish American Newspaper and Periodical Collection (AIA 004)
New York Public Library microfilm copy of Irish Echo (ZY 86-164, 1935-present with significant gaps before 1950)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into seven series, five of which have been further arranged into subseries. All series and subseries are arranged alphabetically. The arrangement of the materials is as follows:
Series IV. The Irish Echo Staff, 1971-2004
Series VI. Film, Television, and Theatre, 1952, 1970-2004

controlaccess.subject: Irish Americans -- Societies, etc.
Irish Americans -- Music.
Irish Americans -- Ethnic identity.
Irish Americans -- Newspapers.
Irish Americans -- New York (State) -- New York -- Political activity.
Irish Americans -- New York (N.Y.) -- Social life and customs.
Irish Americans -- Social life and customs.
controlaccess.title: Irish echo (New York, N.Y.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series comprises the bulk of the collection and consists primarily of photographic prints of various sizes. The contents of this series document Irish American social organizations, political figures and activities, and sporting events, mostly in the greater New York City area. Although some photographs in this series date back to the 1930s and 1940s, the majority of images featured in this series were taken after 1950. This series contains photographs documenting the intersection of the Irish influence on American culture, and is further divided into four subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains photographs of various Irish American organizations and events in the United States. A large number of these photographs document County Societies' functions, banquets, and award ceremonies during the 1970s and 1980s. Other major subjects include Irish American educational institutions and charitable organizations.

did.unittitle: Ancient Order of Hibernians: National Board
Ancient Order of Hibernians: New York County
Ireland Chamber of Commerce United States of America (I.C.C.U.S.A.)
Ireland-United States Council of Commerce and Industry
Irish American Society of Nassau, Suffolk and Queens, NY
Irish Counties: Longford: St. Patrick's Day Ball
New York University Glucksman Ireland House

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains photographs of politically-affiliated Irish American causes, events, and organizations, including photographs documenting efforts made in the United States on behalf of the peace process in Northern Ireland. Common subjects include relief efforts, the 1981 Hunger Strike, and prisoner treatment with overarching themes of Irish unity and solidarity. Politicians who held office in Ireland and/or the United States can be found in Series II. Ireland: Subseries A. Politics and Series III. United States: Subseries B. Politics, respectively.

did.unittitle: Ad Hoc Committee on Irish Affairs
American Protestants for Truth About Ireland
New York City: Pension Fund Investment in Northern Ireland
Omagh Relief Fund of New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries encompasses a range of topics relevant to The Irish Echo's primary readership base: Irish Americans and Irish in America. In addition to subjects covered extensively, such as dance, festivals, and St. Patrick's Day Parades, this subseries also includes a significant number of photographs taken in historically Irish American communities throughout New York City and State. Photographs taken outside of New York are organized by state name followed by additional parenthetical identifiers whenever possible.

did.unittitle: Events: A Day in the Bog
New York (Brooklyn): Cardinal Newman Council Knights of Columbus
New York (Brooklyn): St. Raymond's Gaelic Athletic Association
Pennsylvania: Guinness Weekend in the Poconos
Rose of Tralee: New York Darlin' Girl from Clare
St. Patrick's Day Parade Committee (New York)
St. Patrick's Day Parade Grand Marshals
St. Patrick's Day Parades (outside New York City)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains photographs of Irish sports in America. Extensive documentation of the Gaelic Athletic Association (GAA) and associated groups are complemented by coverage of hurling and soccer. Featured within this subseries is considerable photographic documentation of Gaelic Park from the 1950s through the 1990s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of photographic prints of various sizes, all of which were taken in The Republic of Ireland or Northern Ireland over a period of approximately 65 years. The photographs contained in this series document tourism and tourist attractions in almost all of the Irish counties; major Irish businesses and business leaders; Irish politicians; and Irish athletes and the athletic events. This series contains photographs documenting key aspects of Irish life and is further divided into four subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries is comprised largely of scenic photographs taken in many of the Irish counties. Specific tourist destinations are organized by type, such as churches or pubs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains photographs of prominent Irish businesses and business leaders. Included in this subseries are numerous photographs of Aer Lingus/Irish International Airlines during the 1960s and 1970s. Also featured within this subseries are photographs of assorted smaller Irish businesses, which are featured in General Business folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains photographs of influential politicians from both the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland. Included in this subseries are Sinn Féin President Gerry Adams, former Social Democratic and Labour Party leader John Hume, Presidents of Ireland Éamon de Valera and Mary Robinson, and former Taoisigh Bertie Ahern and Séan Lemass. Other noteworthy individuals appearing in this series include former British Prime Ministers Tony Blair and Margaret Thatcher.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This subseries features images of Irish politicians organized alphabetically by surname; minor politicians, as well as prominent politicians with limited documentation, are featured in the alphabetic sequence prefaced by "Individual Politicians" and followed by a letter.

did.unittitle: Haughey, Charles: Visit to New York City
Hume, John: Irish Echo Man of the Year
Peace People, Committee Of (Betty Williams and Mairead Corrigan)
Robinson, Mary: White House State Dinner

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains photographs of prominent Irish athletes in addition to extensive photographic documentation of Gaelic football.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a variety of photographs capturing moments in Irish life and culture. Major subjects include Irish architecture, Belfast's murals, general news in the country, and documentation of The Troubles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of photographic prints of various sizes. Photos in this series depict American businesses and politicians, as well as sports and athletes that were once the subject of the newspaper's reporting. Noteworthy subjects featured in this series include substantial documentation of Irish restaurants and pubs in America and an approximately 65-year photographic history of New York City's leading politicians. This series is divided into four subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains photographs documenting successful Irish businesses in the United States. Popular subjects include Irish pubs, restaurants, and imports businesses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains photographs of influential American politicians at every level of government, from City Councilmen to President. The politicians in these photos represent a range of ethnic backgrounds over approximately sixty years. The earliest photos in this subseries are of New York City politicians during the 1960s and 1970s, including images of former Mayor William O'Dwyer, a native of Co. Mayo, and of New York State Senator Robert F. Wagner. Also included in this subseries are topical headings, such as "State Politics" and "Women in Politics." An individual's folder, such as Joe Crowley, and a topical folder, like "State Politics," are not mutually exclusive.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains photographs of various American sports, including baseball, American football, boxing, and darts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries is comprised of two folders: Crime; and Labor and Unions.

did.unittitle: Events: New York City Kids' Fest

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of photographic prints and multiple snapshot sequences of The Irish Echo staff at social functions. The contents of this series also include photographs of several members of the Grimes family, proprietors of The Irish Echo from 1955 to 2002. Additional subjects documented in this series include the newspaper's regular and contributing staff.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Because of the fluidity and significance of cultural exchange between communities in Ireland and the United States, this series consists of photographic prints of both Irish and Irish American performers. Notable artists and bands featured in this series include playwright Seamus Heaney, authors Maeve Binchy and Frank McCourt, and musical groups such as The Chieftains and U2. Photographs documenting productions or adaptations of these artists and others are featured in Series VI. Film, Television, Theatre. This series is divided into two subseries.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Contained in this series are two subseries, both of which are organized alphabetically according to artists' surnames or band name. Major artists and bands are listed individually. Lesser known artists and bands are featured in alphabetic sequences prefaced by "Individual Artists" or "General Bands," and then followed by a letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries primarily consists of photographs of Irish and Irish American actors, actresses, writers, musicians, and other performers. Some American artists with ties to the Irish American or Irish communities are also featured. The majority of these photographs are official headshots or taken on location.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries mainly contains photographs of traditional Irish showbands, as well as more contemporary Irish and Irish American bands. Some unaffiliated but extremely influential bands, such as The Beatles, are also included. Noteworthy bands featured in this subseries include The Chieftains, The Dubliners, The Irish Rovers, The Saw Doctors, and U2. The majority of these photos are bands' official publicity shots.

did.unittitle: Series VI. Film, Television, and Theatre, 1952, 1970-2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised primarily of photographic prints from American and Irish film, television, and theatre that were advertised or otherwise featured in The Irish Echo. The majority of photos in this series are either official publicity shots distributed by production studios or snapshots taken on set. This series is further divided into two subseries.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series contains two subseries, both of which are organized alphabetically according to production title. Major works are listed individually. Less prominent films, television shows, and theatrical productions are featured in alphabetic sequences prefaced by "Film and Television" or "Theatre," and then followed by a letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of photographic prints of popular Irish, American, and Irish American films and television, such as My Left Foot and In The Name of the Father, both of which were directed by Irish filmmaker Jim Sheridan. Also included are photographs from a variety of popular or successful American productions, as well as smaller independent pictures, such as The Secret of Roan Inish. The majority of photographs featured in this subseries are from the 1990s and early 2000s.

unittitle.emph: A Day in the Life of Ireland
The Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain
In The Name of the Father
Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels
A Play in the Fields of the Lord
Star Wars Episode I: The Phantom Menace

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of photographic prints of popular Irish and Irish American theatre productions staged in Ireland, primarily Dublin, and in the United States, primarily New York. Featured in this subseries are photographs of significant works including Martin McDonagh's The Beauty Queen of Leenane, Samuel Beckett's Waiting for Godot, and Brian Friel's Dancing at Lughnasa. Photographs of several Shakespearean productions, including Hamlet, King Lear, and A Midsummer's Night Dream, are also included. The majority of photographs featured in this subseries were taken between 1980 and the early 2000s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of photographic prints of various Irish, American, and Irish American individuals. Included in this series is extensive photographic documentation of Roman Catholic clergy from all levels of rank. Additionally, this series features individuals who resist strictly defined categorization (either by qualifying for multiple categories or for none at all) and who can be regarded more generally as public figures of varying degrees of importance. One example is the late Connie Doolan, a celebrated Irish immigration activist; former New York imports representative for Guinness; and a highly successful businessman. Rather than constrain him to a single identifying characteristic, as is the structure for Series I-VI, Doolan is featured in Series VII. Another example is that of Veronica Guerin, who was both a journalist and an activist, and thus is also featured in Series VII.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is unique to the rest of the collection in terms of its ordering scheme. Series VII follows a strict alphabetical arrangement with a general alphabetic sequence dispersed throughout, rather than clustered. For example, following the general "A" folder are the folders for promiment individuals with surnames beginning in A; following that is the general "B" folder and then folders for prominent individuals with surnames beginning in B, continuing through "Z".
